The Herricks Public Schools welcomed new staff members with an orientation in late August, prior to school reopening. Over the course of three days, the new employees had opportunities to meet administrators, learn about district procedures and participate in professional development sessions.

Attendees were greeted by Board of Education President Henry Zanetti, Superintendent Dr. Fino Celano and other members of the Central Administration. They received overviews on the different departments within the district and aspects of the education program, including as mindfulness and the Danielson Framework for Teaching rubric.

The second day featured a Mini Edu Camp that focused on instructional technology. The orientation concluded with presentations on instructional strategies, and the new staff members reported to their home buildings for tours and trainings.

While the 2020-21 school year will be different in light of the pandemic, the district looks forward to opening in September with many bright new team members dedicated to student learning and safety.

Herricks High School senior Shreya Patel was recently selected as a National Merit $2,500 Scholarship winner. She was recognized as National Merit Semifinalist and Finalist in the 65th annual National Merit Scholarship Program earlier this school year after meeting high academic standards and completing other rigorous requirements.

Scholarship award recipients were chosen from the Finalist group based on their abilities, skills and accomplishments.They represent those in each state judged to have the strongest combination of accomplishments, skills, and potential for success in rigorous college studies.

Shreya is an AP Scholar, as well as vice president of Amnesty International and member of the Herricks Helping Hands board. She will be attending Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, in their BS/MD program.

This year, despite the incredible challenges presented by the pandemic, Herricks High School students participated in the New York State Virtual History Day competition with 10 entries. Students won numerous distinctions, and three will now advance to the national level.

First Place (Advancing to Virtual National History Day): Senior Group Website: Gurvir Singh, Karan Kaknia, David Zhang, Aveena Desai, David Xiang -- "The Three Gorges Dam: Progress, but at What Cost?"

Third Place:
Senior Group Documentary: Wafiq Khondkar, Scott McClellan, Chris Zovko -- "The Miracle on the Han River"

Finalists:
Senior Individual Website: Sahit Dokku -- "The Accident That Saved Humanity"
Senior Group Exhibit: Prableen Kaur, Roshni Patel, Sarah Ninan, Amisha Brahmbhatt, Genesis Kang -- "Corazon Aquino: How One Woman Peacefully Broke the Barrier of Filipino Oppression"

We are very proud of the all the students for the work they did. Good luck to Gurvir, Karan, David, Aveena and David - this is their third year competing in the National competition in the senior group website division!

For the second consecutive year, all three Herricks elementary schools have been recognized as Project Lead the Way Distinguished Schools. Center Street, Denton Avenue and Searingtown schools earned this achievement by increasing student access, engagement, and achievement in their PLTW programs, and are among only 404 elementary schools across the country to receive this designation.

To be eligible for the designation, schools had to offer at least two PLTW Launch modules at each grade level and have more than 75 percent of the student body participating during the 2018-19 school year.

Herricks implemented Project Lead the Way in grades K-5 during the 2015-16 school year and has expanded upon it since then. The curriculum emphasizes the STEM components of science, technology, engineering and mathematics, and encompasses four modules: two engineering segments, one biomedicine unit and one computer science element. Collaboration and hands-on engagement are key, as students work together and learn through trial and error to solve problems.

Herricks High School‚Äôs Model United Nations students spent weeks participating in a virtual conference that simulated the World Health Organization and explored the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The delegates formed three committees that represented various countries and collaborated on solving critical issues that have arisen as a result of the pandemic.

Through their debates, the delegates came together to pass four comprehensive working papers. On April 24, under the guidance of teachers Chloe Graef and Leigh Candalino, the Model UN club hosted a Plenary debate and voted on a resolution that was created by the participants.

After three hours of deliberation, the final resolution was developed and included solutions that pertained to 5 main sectors: economic responses, social responses, government responses, medical responses, and international collaboration. The Herricks students were joined by a group from Locust Valley that also voted on the resolution, which will now be sent to the World Health Organization for review.

Center Street School provided food and positive thoughts to North Shore Hospital as a way to thank the medical staff for their tremendous efforts during these times.

Through the school-based Community Connection Committee, students were invited to write letters and cards for hospital workers and parents contributed monetary donations for food. Teacher and Service Club adviser Janine Gentile collected the notes and PTA Co-President Dawnmarie Muzikant arranged for food to be delivered from a local Subway that is owned by a Center Street family.

Thanks to these collaborative efforts, Center Street was able to send food to all four floors of COVID-19 ICU at the hospital. Herricks thanks all the front line workers!
